Description: Grey-brown pottery pilgrim-flask with circular body, short neck and two handles, the fabric is very worn. On side (a), within a plain border, Saint Menas stands to front, his arms outstretched in blessing. Above each arm is a cross. The mould-pressed impression of the saint is featureless, but he wears a short tunic; no cloak is visible. He is flanked by camels. On side (b), within a wreath-border, is a cross, surrounded by an inscription in relief, probably, but it cannot be read due to a covering of concretion.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired at Damanhur. Late Roman, about AD 480-650. Comparandum: Side (a): near: Petrie Museum uc65096.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3440)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
